footer.tagline: Sustainably reusing technology, enabling digital access, and empowering communities since 2000.
footer.since: Turning e-waste into opportunity since Earth Day, 2000.

hero.description: We turn e-waste into opportunity. For 25 years, we've been keeping tech out of landfills and putting it into the hands of people who need it most.

stats.ewaste: Pounds of e-waste saved from landfills
stats.devices: Devices given to people in need

problem.title: Two crises. One solution.
problem.ewaste: E-waste is just 2% of America's trash—but 70% of its toxic waste. Most ends up in landfills, poisoning soil and water.
problem.access: American households don't have a computer. No computer means no job applications, no homework, no telehealth, no connection.
problem.solution: We take devices people no longer need and give them to people who do. It's not charity—it's common sense.

donate.title: You donate
donate.description: Drop off laptops, desktops, phones—anything with a plug. We wipe your data securely.

refurbish.title: We refurbish
refurbish.description: Our team rebuilds what can be saved (~30%). What can't gets responsibly recycled for materials recovery (~70%).

distribute.title: They thrive
distribute.description: A student gets a laptop for school. A job seeker sends their first resume. A grandma video-calls her family.

community.title: Digital inclusion is a social justice issue
community.p1: Without technology access, full participation in American society is impossible. Jobs, education, healthcare, civic engagement—all require being connected.
community.p2: The digital divide hits hardest for low-income families, immigrants, seniors, people with disabilities, and communities of color. We're here to change that.

cta.title: Got old tech collecting dust?
cta.description: That laptop in your closet could change someone's life. Drop it off, and we'll handle the rest.

hero.description: Since Earth Day 2000, we've been turning e-waste into opportunity—keeping tech out of landfills and putting it into the hands of people who need it most.

origin.title: Our Origin Story
origin.p1: Free Geek launched at Pioneer Courthouse Square on Earth Day 2000. That September, we opened our doors on SE 10th Avenue as a drop-off for electronic waste—salvaging technology before it hit landfills.
origin.p2: Over 25 years, we've evolved from a recycling center into a digital inclusion powerhouse. Our reuse and recycling programs still form our backbone, providing the refurbished devices we put back into the community.
origin.p3: But today, our core mission is narrowing the digital divide—ensuring everyone has access to technology and the skills to use it.

mission.title: Our Mission
mission.text: To sustainably reuse technology, enable digital access, and provide education to create a community that empowers people to realize their potential.
mission.statement: To sustainably reuse technology, enable digital access, and provide education to create a community that empowers people to realize their potential.

digitalDivide.title: The Digital Divide
digitalDivide.p1: 27% of Americans don't own a computer. One in ten families lack home internet. This gap falls hardest on low-income families, immigrants, seniors, and communities of color.
digitalDivide.p2: Without technology access, full participation in American society—jobs, education, healthcare, civic engagement—is compromised. This is a social justice issue.

ewaste.title: The E-Waste Crisis
ewaste.p1: Only 27% of e-waste gets recycled nationally. E-waste is just 2% of America's landfill trash—but 70% of its toxic waste.
ewaste.p2: Most "e-waste" isn't waste at all. It's perfectly good equipment that can be repaired, refurbished, and given new life.

circular.title: The Circular Model
circular.description: We point these two problems at each other. The computers we grant to Digital Inclusion participants are saved from landfills and go on to help our community's most vulnerable populations build the digital skills they need to thrive.

cta.title: Ready to get involved?
cta.description: Whether you donate tech, volunteer your time, or support us financially, you're helping bridge the digital divide.

hero.description: 27% of Americans don't own a computer. We're working to change that with free and low-cost technology for individuals and organizations.

individuals.title: Plug Into Portland
individuals.p1: Our flagship program for individuals who need a computer. Apply to get on the waitlist for a free laptop running Linux Mint, with a one-year warranty and Digital Navigation Support.
individuals.p2: Currently, 75,000 Oregon students don't have a personal computer to complete their assignments. We're here to close that gap.
individuals.description: Our flagship program for individuals who need a computer. Apply to get on the waitlist for a free laptop running Linux Mint, with a one-year warranty and Digital Navigation Support.
individuals.stats: Currently, 75,000 Oregon students don't have a personal computer to complete their assignments. We're here to close that gap.

organizations.title: Hardware Grants & Affordable Tech
organizations.description: Free Geek supports nonprofits and community organizations with technology. Whether you need devices for your staff or the communities you serve, we have programs to help.

shop.title: Need a computer now?
shop.description: If you're not eligible for our free programs or can't wait for the waitlist, you can purchase quality refurbished computers from our online shop at affordable prices.

gap.title: The homework gap is real
gap.p1: The "homework gap" describes the difficulty students face completing assignments without access to a device or internet at home. In Oregon alone, 75,000 students lack a personal computer for schoolwork.
gap.p2: When we put a computer in a student's hands, we're not just giving them a device—we're giving them the ability to do their homework, apply for jobs, connect with family, and participate fully in our digital world.

homeworkGap.title: The homework gap is real
homeworkGap.p1: The "homework gap" describes the difficulty students face completing assignments without access to a device or internet at home. In Oregon alone, 75,000 students lack a personal computer for schoolwork.
homeworkGap.p2: When we put a computer in a student's hands, we're not just giving them a device—we're giving them the ability to do their homework, apply for jobs, connect with family, and participate fully in our digital world.

testimonial.quote: We at A Family for Every Child unconditionally support Free Geek; they serve an irreplaceable role in our community. Were it not for the generous past donations of Free Geek, we would neither be able to function during this health crisis, nor serve our mission as a whole.
testimonial.author: Andrew Hampton, A Family for Every Child

equity.title: What is Digital Equity?
equity.description: Digital equity is a condition in which all individuals and communities have the information technology capacity needed for full participation in our society, democracy, and economy. It is necessary for civic and cultural participation, employment, lifelong learning, and access to essential services.
